Results: Novak Djokovic defended his singles title, winning a record-equaling 6th title. Germany's Angelique Kerber beat defending champion Serena Williams.
This 15th consecutive Winter X Games held in Aspen included 8 skiing events, 9 snowboarding events, and 3 snowmobiling events. USA won the most gold, with 8.
Denver Broncos defeated the Carolina Panthers 24-10. The MVP was Von Miller of the Denver Broncos.
Hosts Great Britain finished top of the medal table with 5 gold.
In the final the West Indies defeated England by four wickets. Indian batsman Virat Kohli was named the player of the tournament.
Danny Willett won with a score of 283 (–5), beating defending champion Jordan Spieth.
Won by 33/1 shot 'Rule The World'
Both of the winners were from Ethiopia: Lemi Berhanu Hayle (men) won in a time of 2:12:45, Atsede Baysa (women) won with a time of 2:29:19.
Canada won their 26th gold medal, defeating Finland 2–0 in the gold medal game.
won by undefeated 3-1 favorite Nyquist.
15 countries participated
In a repeat of the 1990 FA Cup Final, Manchester United defeated Crystal Palace.

Novak Djokovic won the men's singles, making a career Grand Slam. Roger Federer withdrew before the tournament due to an injury, the first Grand Slam he has missed since 2000. The women's was won by Spain's Garbiñe Muguruza, her first Grand Slam victory.

Played between Spanish teams Real Madrid and Atlético Madrid, a repeat of the 2014 final and the 2nd time that both finalists were from the same city. Real Madrid won 5–3 on a penalty shoot-out after a 1–1 draw at the end of extra time.
The Pittsburgh Penguins defeated San Jose Sharks 4 games to 2 to win their fourth championship. For the first time since 2011, an Eastern Conference team won the Stanley Cup.
Cleveland Cavaliers defeated Golden State Warriors 4-3. The Cavaliers became the first team ever to recover from a three games to one deficit. LeBron James was named NBA Finals MVP.
Chile defeated Argentina in the final, becoming the 4th nation to win at least two consecutive Copa América titles.
Portugal shocked France with a 1-0 extra time victory in the final.
Dustin Johnson won by three shots to claim his first major championship.
Andy Murray won his 2nd Wimbledon, and Serena Williams her 7th. Williams equaled Steffi Graf's Open era record of 22 major singles titles.
The winner was the UK rider Chris Froome of Team Sky, his third win in four years. He finished ahead of French rider Romain Bardet (AG2R) and Colombia's Nairo Quintana (Movistar).

Location: Royal Troon Golf Club, Ayrshire, Scotland
Results: won by Henrik Stenson who achieved a record 20 under par.
Jimmy Walker from the US won his first major title in an exciting finish one stroke ahead of the defending champion and world's no.1 Australian Jason Day.
USA led the medal tally in both gold and total medals. Team GB surprised and was second in terms of golds ahead of China. Nearly 60 countries won at least one gold, and 87 at least one medal
Stan Wawrinka defeated defending champion Novak Djokovic in the men's final and Angelique Kerber defeated Karolína Plíšková in the women's singles final.
Japan won their 5th title
12 years after the previous World Cup of Hockey, won by Canada.
The US won its first Ryder Cup title in eight years with a 17-11 victory over Europe
The western Bulldogs beat the Sydney Swans, winning their first premiership since 1954, breaking a 62-year drought
The Chicago Cubs defeated the Indians in seven games to win their first World Series in 108 years.
Almandin produced a strong late run to catch Heartbreak City in the final strides and win by a head

Possibly the largest marathon ever held with over 51,000 runners. Eritrea's Ghirmay Ghebreslassie was the fastest man in a time of 2 hours, 7 minutes, 51 seconds. Kenyan Mary Keitany won her third straight women's title in a time of 2 hours, 24 minutes, 26 seconds.
